questions.stem: The two most clinically important equine herpesviruses are:
questions.explanation: EHV-1 and EHV-4 are the most clinically important types, both causing respiratory disease. EHV-1 may also cause abortion or neurologic disease. EHV-2 and EHV-3 (A), EHV-5 and EHV-6 (C), and EHV-7 and EHV-8 (D) are less commonly clinically significant.

questions.stem: EHV-4 primarily causes:
questions.explanation: EHV-4 primarily causes respiratory disease. Neurologic disease (A) and abortion (C) are associated with EHV-1. Genital lesions (D) are caused by EHV-3.

questions.stem: EHV-1 can cause all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: EHV-1 causes respiratory disease (A), late-term abortion (B), and neurologic disease (C). Genital lesions are caused by EHV-3, not EHV-1.

questions.stem: Equine herpesviruses establish:

options.label: A
options.text: Acute infection only, cleared within weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Latency, with infected horses remaining lifelong carriers

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic active infection requiring continuous treatment

questions.explanation: Equine herpesviruses establish latency, with infected horses remaining lifelong carriers. They do not cause only acute infection (A), chronic active infection (C), or no persistent infection (D).

questions.stem: Transmission of EHV occurs primarily through:

options.label: B
options.text: Nasal secretions, aborted materials, or fomites

questions.explanation: Transmission occurs through nasal secretions, aborted materials, or fomites. It is not primarily airborne over long distances (A), vertically transmitted only (C), or through feed ingestion (D).

questions.stem: Which age group is MOST susceptible to respiratory disease caused by EHV?
questions.explanation: Younger horses (weanlings/yearlings) are most susceptible to respiratory disease. Geriatric horses (A), adult horses (B), and equal distribution (D) are not the most susceptible groups.

questions.stem: Pregnant mares are at risk for abortion due to EHV-1 during:
questions.explanation: Pregnant mares are at risk for abortion due to EHV-1 during months 7–11 of gestation. Earlier months (A, B) or only the first month (D) are not the typical risk period.

questions.stem: Clinical signs of the respiratory form of EHV include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Profuse watery diarrhea is not a typical sign of respiratory EHV. Fever and nasal discharge (A), cough and swollen lymph nodes (B), and depression and anorexia (C) are common signs.

questions.stem: The neurologic form of EHV-1 (EHM) is characterized by:

options.label: B
options.text: Ataxia, hind-limb weakness, urinary retention, and paralysis

questions.explanation: The neurologic form (EHM) is characterized by ataxia, hind-limb weakness, urinary retention, and paralysis, which may progress to recumbency or death. Seizures and blindness (A), head pressing and circling (C), and hyperexcitability (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Aborted fetuses from EHV-1 infection typically show:

options.label: B
options.text: Fresh appearance with minimal autolysis, white necrotic foci on liver

questions.explanation: Aborted fetuses from EHV-1 infection typically appear fresh with minimal autolysis and show white necrotic foci ("target lesions") on the liver. Severe autolysis (A), no visible lesions (C), or only placental abnormalities (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: The gold standard diagnostic test for EHV is:

options.label: C
options.text: PCR on nasal swabs and blood (buffy coat)

questions.explanation: PCR on nasal swabs and blood (buffy coat) is the gold standard diagnostic test. Serology (A) and culture (B) are less sensitive, and CBC (D) is not diagnostic.

questions.stem: CSF analysis in neurologic EHV cases typically shows:

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased protein and red blood cells

questions.explanation: CSF analysis in neurologic EHV cases typically shows increased protein and xanthochromia. Normal CSF (A), decreased protein (C), or no abnormalities (D) are not typical findings.

questions.stem: Treatment of EHV respiratory disease primarily consists of:

options.label: B
options.text: Supportive care including rest, hydration, and NSAIDs for fever

questions.explanation: Treatment of respiratory EHV primarily consists of supportive care including rest, hydration, and NSAIDs for fever. Antivirals (A) are used for neurologic cases, not routine respiratory disease. Corticosteroids (C) and surgery (D) are not primary treatments.

questions.stem: Antiviral therapy for EHM cases may include:

options.label: A
options.text: Acyclovir (10 mg/kg, PO, 5 times per day) or valacyclovir (30 mg/kg, PO, q 6–8 h)

questions.explanation: Antiviral therapy for EHM may include acyclovir (10 mg/kg, PO, 5 times per day) or valacyclovir (30 mg/kg, PO, q 6–8 h). Ganciclovir (B), ribavirin (C), or no antivirals (D) are not standard treatments.

questions.stem: The prognosis for horses with neuropathic EHV-1 that remain ambulatory or are recumbent for only 2–3 days is:
questions.explanation: The prognosis for horses with neuropathic EHV-1 that remain ambulatory or are recumbent for only 2–3 days is usually favorable. Poor prognosis (A), guarded with permanent deficits (C), or unknown (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Most foals infected prenatally with EHV-1:

options.label: B
options.text: Die shortly after birth despite intensive care

questions.explanation: Most foals infected prenatally with EHV-1 die shortly after birth despite intensive nursing and antimicrobial medication. Recovery (A), no clinical signs (C), or mild signs (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: EHV virus survives on surfaces for approximately:
questions.explanation: EHV virus survives approximately 48 hours on surfaces. Shorter (A) or longer survival times (C, D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: New horses should be isolated for how long to prevent EHV introduction?
questions.explanation: New horses should be isolated for 21 days to prevent EHV introduction. Shorter periods (A, B) may be insufficient, and longer periods (D) are typically unnecessary.

questions.stem: During an EHV outbreak, affected and in-contact horses should be isolated for:
questions.explanation: During an EHV outbreak, affected and in-contact horses should be isolated for 28 days. Shorter periods (A, B) or longer (D) are not standard recommendations.

questions.stem: Pregnant mares should be vaccinated against EHV-1 at:
questions.explanation: Pregnant mares should be vaccinated against EHV-1 at 3, 5, 7, and 9 months of gestation. Other schedules (A, C) or no vaccination (D) are not recommended.

questions.stem: A high-antigen load, inactivated EHV-1 vaccine is recommended to prevent:
questions.explanation: A high-antigen load, inactivated EHV-1 vaccine is recommended to prevent EHV-1 abortion. Respiratory disease (A), neurologic disease (C), or all forms (D) are not the primary indication for this vaccine.

questions.stem: Vaccination for EHV should begin in foals at:
questions.explanation: Vaccination for EHV should begin in foals at 4–6 months of age. Earlier (A, B) or later (D) timing is not standard.

questions.stem: Booster vaccinations for EHV may be indicated as often as every:
questions.explanation: Booster vaccinations for EHV may be indicated as often as every 6 months through maturity (5 years of age). More frequent (A) or less frequent (C, D) intervals are not standard.

questions.stem: EHV-2 (gammaherpesvirus) is associated with:

options.label: B
options.text: Conjunctivitis, respiratory issues, and poor performance

questions.explanation: EHV-2 (gammaherpesvirus) is associated with conjunctivitis, respiratory issues, and poor performance. Abortion (A), neurologic disease (C), or genital lesions only (D) are not associated with EHV-2.

questions.stem: EHV-3 (coital exanthema virus) causes:

options.label: B
options.text: Genital lesions — vesicles, pustules, and ulcers on vulva or penis

questions.explanation: EHV-3 (coital exanthema virus) causes genital lesions — vesicles, pustules, and ulcers on vulva or penis, spread via breeding or contaminated instruments. Respiratory disease (A), abortion (C), or neurologic signs (D) are not caused by EHV-3.

questions.stem: EHV-5 is associated with:
questions.explanation: EHV-5 is associated with Equine Multinodular Pulmonary Fibrosis (EMPF), a chronic fibrotic lung disease. Abortion (B), neurologic disease (C), or genital lesions (D) are not associated with EHV-5.

questions.stem: Currently available EHV vaccines:

options.label: A
options.text: Offer comprehensive protection against all forms of EHV disease

options.label: B
options.text: Do not offer comprehensive protection against EHV-1-associated abortion and EHM

questions.explanation: Currently available EHV vaccines do not offer comprehensive protection against EHV-1-associated abortion and EHM. They do not offer comprehensive protection (A), are not limited to foals (C), and are recommended (D).

questions.stem: USEF events require documentation of EHV vaccination within:
questions.explanation: USEF events require documentation of EHV vaccination (and equine influenza virus) within 6 months of entering event grounds. Shorter (A) or longer (C) periods, or no requirement (D), are not correct.
